My niece's wedding in 2022. She said, "I know you love ABBA and I want the DJ to play an ABBA song at the reception.  Which song would you suggest?" I said, "NO DANCING QUEEN!" (because that is always the obvious choice).  I wanted a song that the average casual ABBA listener most likely had never heard of, and one I loved. 'As Good As new' was it!  Also, my niece and her boyfriend had been together for 10 years, so this wedding was to make their relationship 'as good as new.'  During the reception, the music was pretty lame. An hour later, my niece approached us and said, "He has not played your song yet?" I said no. She marched over to the DJ.....and within 5 minutes, the strings we know and love came on.  Everyone stopped. What was this???  Then the strings stopped and the song hit!  I knew people would jump. I dragged my niece (still in her wedding gown!) and my partner to the dance floor and we let it loose.  And the dance floor, which was almost empty until now, was suddenly full.  People loved this!  And it forced the DJ to finally start playing great music to follow.  I have known and loved this song since 1979 and now, every time I hear it, I think of Gabrielle's wedding.

'I Am The City' recorded the 5th May 1982 during sessions for ABBA's 9th album that was never completed, its a really good song very catchy and has hit single potential. 'I Am The City' remained unreleased for 11 years when it was finally included on the 1993 compilation album 'More ABBA Gold', in 2012 the song was included on the Deluxe Edition of 'The Visitors'.

Bought a collection at the age of 10. I had the chance to listen to many ABBA songs that I didn't know until then. And without internet it was always an adventure to go and buy records/CDs and then listen to them.

I remember seeing an english advertising of ABBA-books in my original homecountry Germany and at that time writing an order on paper in the best english I was able to, went to the bank and exchanged Deutschmarks to Pounds, putting them in an envelope, sending the letter and the money to London and after several weeks I got my fucking stunning ABBA-books!!

That was life! :)

Just when I thought they couldn't top themselves, I finally got to "The Visitors" album, and heard this GORGEOUS song. It brings a lump in my throat every single time. The melody, the arrangements, the lyrics, Frida's outstanding vocals (one of her very best), the harmonies... This song deserves a higher profile. What a jewel.

Ace of Base is a Swedish pop group, formed in 1990, originally consisting of siblings Jonas, Linn, and Jenny Berggren, with Ulf Ekberg.

They continued to score hit singles throughout the 1990s, with songs such as "Beautiful Life", "Lucky Love", "Cruel Summer" and "Life Is a Flower". The group has sold 50 million copies of their first four studio albums, making them the third most successful Swedish group of all time, behind ABBA and Roxette.

Why Adele's fans are called Daydreamers?

Adele's fans are referred to as "Daydreamers" because of her song "Daydreamer" from her debut album "19." The term has since become a way for her fans to identify themselves and connect with her music. The name reflects the emotional and introspective nature of Adele's songs, which often evoke deep feelings and reflections, akin to the act of daydreaming.

In her song "Daydreamer" she described her first crush on this perfect boy from her childhood. In an open interview she once said that "Daydreamer" is basically her dream man, her ideal perfect man. Although she can never have such a person in her life (as claimed by her), her fans adopted the name "Daydreamers" to commemorate that even though she may not have that perfect man, she will always have us. The fans will become her Daydreamers.

hey i hope you're doing well, i'm sure you've accomplished things during the times we're apart and i'm very happy for you, like really. i know we're no longer in communication, no more birthday or christmas greetings but i'd still greet you if i really wanted to. i'm glad we chose to protect our own peace because this is for the best. however, on some nights, you're all i think about even though that feels uncomfortable to admit since it's been 2+ years. i remember when you dedicated this song to me when we were talking, and i really can't believe how much time has flown. it feels like we were fourteen yesterday and now we're turning 18 next year. meanwhile, i'll be keeping my promise, rooting for you from far away. maybe you'll read this? well i don't know and i don't think so haha. i'm happy i met you because thanks to you, i've learnt how to love myself and maybe someone else in the future, at the right time? other than that, you were the first boy who made me feel like this, i'm serious. but i'm thankful for that. i'll always remember the cheesy pickup lines and the good mornings and have you eaten's, and the songs we shared with each other, like this one. i'll really really really treasure you even though we've closed this chapter for a very long time. always take care  :)

My darling son aged 18 was horrifically murdered 4 years ago today, 29 April 2019. He loved ABBA. He used to listen to them in different languages. I grew up with ABBA buying all their singles from age 12. I have not been able to listen to these fine musicians since. This song has just come up on the main page. I still can't listen to it all the way through.

I have listened to many wonderful pieces of music in my 74 years. This particular piece goes beyond a treat for the ears, this piece goes straight to the soul of the listener. It can only be described as musical perfection. The clock becomes a percussion instrument, each beat is one step closer to the fate that awaits us all, it has no regard about life, it will keep ticking weather we are here or not, the fact that the clock stops at the end of the song tells us the fate of the person in the song. The orchestral accompanyment is partially muted, as an older person might hear it. Even the room acoustics are right, very little reverb as one would expect in a small room with soft furnishings. As one becomes older and sees our parents and loved ones go before us, this song has tremendous relevance. Magnificent!!!!!
A true masterpiece, Frida at her best

This track is from the Abba Waterloo album, one of the most crimminally underestimated albums of all time.  Three other very great albums, obviously by the Beatles, are Sgy Pepper, Rubber soul, and Revolver, and the Waterloo album can live in this kind of company.  
The two blistering tracks, are Suzy hang around, a worthy number one, and the one that did get the attention it deserved, Waterloo.  

What about Livingstone is worth a top three hit, and Hasta Mannan and  Dance while th emusic still goes on are top five worthy hits.  Honey honey is also worth a top five.  And yet nother worthy of a top three hit is the huantingly Gonna sing you my love song.  It is amazing that My Mamma said appears to be one of the more medium strength tracks.  But waht is medium for Abba, or the 1970s, makes a mockery of what passes for so called music in current times.  Many of the B-sides of the 1970s simply blast out of the water most modern music, so called.  

It's when you listen to My Mamma through headphones on a good sound system, that you notice Abba packed a llot more than first appears, into into an upper medium song.  Does it have a slightly tropical feel to it, with some of the instruments used?  A lot of commentators on this Youtube clip clearly know their music, and picked up on the funk aspects of this song.  

Back in the 60s and 70s the Eurovision song contest did used to be reasonably good.  Many teenagers would watch, but then so would would families and even grannies.  Very pop based Puppett on as tring was the usual fair.  Abba were quite daring using the very Rock based Waterloo.  Some middle aged people of the time possibly never got over the shock.  A Eurovison band could be a bit gimmicky, and on an album you find the Eurovision winner and at best two medium tracks and a lot of fillers, two of which sounded like rewrokings of the big hit.  But with Abba Waterloo you get an astonishingly good album, almsot full of top five hits.  The weakest tracks, well weak for Abba smashes the output of other bands to pieces, are Watch out, Sitting in the palm tree, and King Kong Song.  But King kong is still good value, it's a bit wild, and lots of fun.

To my opinion most underrated Alabama song that didn't make the top charts, they had 42 #1 HITS in the country music scene but it's songs like this that makes this group the best country group ever and always will be.

This song was written by Jimmy McBride, of Huntsville, Alabama. It was written about the neighborhood my daddy grew up in. (Jimmy grew up on the street behind my dad). Jimmy worked at the post office with my daddy and his father for nine years. Then he started writing songs, his first was "bridge that just won't burn" recorded by Conway Twitty. I remember when Me. McBride gave me a cassette tape of a rough cut if that song, and how proud of Jimmy we all were when I played it for mama, granny, daddy, and my uncle's....Jimmy went on to co write some quite famous songs, "chasin that neon rainbow", and "Chattahoochee" by Alan Jackson. It's amazing to hear a song that's about a place you grew up......Billy Ray Morrison Jr....

This song is one of my earliest firm memories. I was born in 1977. My brother and I had a little radio in our shared bedroom, and our dad would tune into Y-100 out of Daytona Beach before bed every night. Alan Parsons Project, John Cougar Mellencamp, Taco (Puttin‚Äô on the Ritz), ABBA, Steve Miller Band, Survivor, Christopher Cross, The Go-Go‚Äôs, Juice Newton‚Ä¶ I would lay there, almost holding my breath so I could hear every note. That little transistor radio planted some very big seeds in my little head. 

Like many of you, I was SO fortunate to have spent my formative years in an era when the musicians on the radio still had legitimate talent.
"The sun in your eyes, made some of the lies worth believing." - is one of the most brilliant/beautiful lyrics I have ever heard!

" ERIC WOOLFSON was the main songwriter and lyricist for the APP writing 95% of the music and 100% of the lyrics. He also sang lead vocal on many of the APP‚Äôs greatest hits including ‚ÄòEye in the Sky‚Äô, ‚ÄòTime‚Äô and ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Answer Me‚Äô. He played keyboards on practically every APP track recorded. He was also the manager of the APP and handled all the business side. It was his decision to call it ‚ÄòThe Alan Parsons Project‚Äô ‚Äì a choice he often described as both the best and worst in his career. The best because he got to enjoy the success of his work without any of the fame. The worst in that generally no one outside the music industry had a clue who he was! "

It was the late 1982 or early 1983 when my neighbor (then in Southern Finland) found a C-tape in a snowbank. It had the letters "A.P.P." scribbled on the label. She gave it to me to find out what was on it, and that's when I first listened to Eye in the Sky. About a month passed until a friend of mine at school came across an article in a music magazine (ah the times before the Web) about The Alan Parsons Project and so the mystery of the "A.P.P." abbreviation was solved. Needless to say, the album is permanently etched in my mind and strongly associated with the 80's (and with my "former life" in Finland).

I've been searching for this song for the last 42 years.
I heard it as a child, 11 years old in 1981, standing in a pizza joint in Queens with my mom. 
I can't tell you how many times over the years I've tried to sing a part of the melody- (To the sea, to the sea'Til it's gone foreverGone forever) the only part that I remembered- to someone to see if they knew it.
When the internet came round, every once in a while I would google the bit of lyric I remembered "to the sea" or look up lists of radio hits from 1981.
Incredibly, I heard it once again only yesterday. It came on the mix at a restaurant and I had the strangest feeling come over me as I began to recognize it.
Shazam this! I yelled at my friends. They all knew it of course.
I came home and sat here listening to the song, feeling myself looking back in time at my child self, both of us transfixed. It felt mystical. Like some kind of miracle to hear it again. And so strange that the lyrics were about time, and I felt myself a part of that river of self and time, grown now but still standing, as if in both places.
I'm only sharing this  because I started to read all the other comments and saw how so many people connect deeply with this song, and I want my tears to join in with theirs...

As a kid, you loved the melody.

As an adult, you understood the lyrics.
Tears are streaming down my face reading the heartfelt comments left here

I had the biggest crush on a girl named Jenny since I was in the 6th grade in 1981. She was a year older than me and never knew I liked her. I was always afraid to tell her. I would see her and always wanted to tell her but never did. Finally, in my junior year in high school (her senior year) at a school dance, the last one of the year, one of the last few songs of the night, this song came on. I spotted her across the room and said to myself, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs now or never.‚Äù I summoned up all the courage I had and went over to her and asked her to dance. She said, ‚ÄúAbsolutely!‚Äù We strode over to the dance floor and started slow dancing. I couldn‚Äôt believe it was actually happening. She was tired from dancing all night and just laid her head on my shoulder as we danced. Time seemed to stand still as I couldn‚Äôt believe the girl of my dreams was here and dancing with me so close. Then before I knew it, the song ended. She hugged me and went back to her friends and I went back to mine and sat back and soaked it all in. She graduated and I never got to tell her how I felt and never saw her again. But for one moment in time, I had the girls of my dreams in my arms for five minutes and eleven seconds. I often think about her. A few years ago, I sent her a friend request on FB and she accepted. I check in on her FB every now and then. I wonder if she even remembers the dance, probably not, but I will remember it for a lifetime and that‚Äôs okay.

Leaving Lepidoptera... Please don't touch the display, little boy. hoho how cute. Moving to the next aisle, we have Arachnida, the spiders, our finest collection. This friendly, little devil is the Heptithilidae, unfortunately harmless. Next to him... the nasty Lycosa Raptoria. His tiny fangs cause creeping ulcerations of the skin. And here... my prize, The Black Widow. Isn't she lovely? And so deadly. Her kiss is fifteen times as poisonous as that of the rattlesnake. You see, her venom is highly neurotoxic. Which is to say that it attacks the central nervous system; causing intense pain, profuse sweating, difficulty in breathing, loss of consciousness, violent convulsions, and, finally... uh, death. You know, what I think I love the most about her is her in-born need to dominate, posses. In fact, immediately after the consummation of her marriage to the smaller and weaker male of the specie, she kills and eats him. Oo-hoo, she is delicious! (And I hope he was.) such power and dignity, unhampered by sentiment, If I may put forward a slice of personal philosophy, I feel that Man has ruled this world as a stumbling, demented child-king long enough! And as his empire crumbles, my precious Black Widow shall rise as his most fitting successor!

Duane Allman was a badass! One of the greatest guitarists ever... I've heard some amazing guitarists in my time, such as Terry Kath, Steve Howe, Alex Lifeson, Stevie Ray Vaughan, Jimi Hendrix, Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page, Pete Townsend, Eric Clapton, Frank Zappa, etc. etc. etc., but Duane was absolutely up there, at the very top of the list, with the best of them! And he did something with that Les Paul that no one else could ever replicate or duplicate. Magic.

The Bilbao Song by Andy Williams officia: This is one my earliest, best memories  - my mom singing along to this song.

I first heard this song on the radio in the fall of 1964 on WWDC in Washington, DC. It was played frequently enough that I thought it was a current song. It took me at least 40 years to find out the title and who had the hit with it, 3 years earlier. I thought maybe someone had a remake release of this 1961 hit in fall 1964, but I haven't been able to find one. Probably the disk jockey especially liked this song and played it a lot that year.

Misheard lyrics - I thought the singer was saying, "That old Bill Bowers moon," and I found the real title by Googling these lyrics. I guess I wasn't the only one who heard them that way!

I first learned the phrase "chug-a-lug" in both this song and "Chug-A-Lug" by Roger Miller, which really was a fall 1964 hit, but I didn't know what it meant until several years later. (I was 12 in fall 1964.)

Finally, I thought I remembered Ray Charles being part of the artist name for "That Old Bill Bowers Moon", but neither Ray Charles nor the Ray Charles Singers appears to have recorded "The Bilbao Song" in 1964 or any other year.
The background singers are great in this song!

Shenandoah by Arlo Guthrie official: What a beautiful rendition of this wonderful song from our heritage!  I love Arlo and his heartfelt songs!

Well.  A chance for once to hear the whole story, as I never have in all the versions I have heard and sung.  I have thought all my life it is one of the whole world's most beautiful melodies, and maybe the finest ever to come out of America.  Praise to Arlo Guthrie for letting the melody take care of itself, and giving the listener the plain and moving narrative with a clear delivery.

Arlo Guthrie is the last survivor of a tradition of American folk music that goes back hundreds of years. Listening to Arlo Guthrie sang this is like listening to the entire history of American folk music.

I've been on a quest for many years to find this version put to record. It was the version sung to me by my father and my grandfather. A story between a mountain man a Native American, daughter of  Shenandoah. Thank you for the upload. My grandfather and father are both long gone but now I have this.
thank you, arlo !!!!!!!
No words can express how much I love this song, and this version of it especially.
These songs had such depth,they attached to our soul.
Arlo is a truly beautiful soul.

In this, it's earliest recorded form, dating from the 1840s, Shennandoah or Shanadore most likely originated with the fur trappers or flatboatmen who traveled the Missouri River in their canoes in this period. The song traveled down the Mississippi to to New Orleans to the coast, where it was picked up by sailors as a Sea Shanty, and was saved from oblivion in an article in 1876 written around sailor's songs. 

I think it one of America's most beautiful and poignant songs in it's original form. It foreshadows what shortly befall Native Americans from the perspective of the white beaver trappers who saw what was coming. 

Shennandoah is an Indian chief of the Oneida Iroquois tribe, and he has a lovely daughter. A white trader and she fall in love, and the trader wants to take her away, offering money, which the chief disdains. Afterwards, a Yankee skipper comes along and steals her away anyways. At the end of the song, she sings from afar of missing hearing her father's voice.

Shennandoah is wonderful in the way it portrays America's western advancing inevitability, and it's repercussions forever for those in our ancestor's path. It is interesting in the way it describes the events in a neutral way, not claiming the whites as superior nor the indians as inferior. The love affair levels the field, depicting all as people, and the love as doomed as the cutlure being run down by the advancement of the encroaching newcomers from the east. 

With it's touching lyrics and soaring, rolling tune, it deserves to be remembered in it's original state. Through much of the 20th century, it has suffered from a lack of honesty- being dumbed down and whitewashed into a meaningless jumble of words which remove it's powerful message of humanity and suffering. America, and especially native Americans deserve better. This is a gem, one of our National Treasures that needs remembered for as long as our country stands.

Interesting tidbits from Wikipedia: 

=====================

The Oneida oral tradition tells that Chief Skenandoa provided critical food, sending corn to General George Washington and his men during their harsh winter at Valley Forge in 1777-1778. Washington is said to have named the Shenandoah River and valley in his honor, and subsequently numerous other places in the United States were named Shenandoah. He is also referred to in the title and lyrics of the folk song "Oh Shenandoah".

=====================
Skenandoa lived into great old age. Nearing the end of his life and having gone blind, the chief is recorded as having said:

"I am an aged hemlock*. I am dead at the top. The winds of an hundred winters have whistled through my branches. Why my Jesus keeps me here so long, I cannot conceive. Pray ye to him, that I may have patience to endure till my time may come."

After Skenandoah died in 1816 at well over a hundred years old, he was buried upon his request (and with the Kirkland family's approval) next to his friend Kirkland, who had died in 1808, on the grounds of Kirkland's home in Clinton, New York. Today the property is known as Harding Farm. As a measure of the respect for the chief, the procession at his funeral in 1816 included students and officers from Hamilton College, the widow Mrs. Kirkland and other members of her family, and numerous town residents, in addition to his son and members of his family and nation. In 1851, both bodies were reinterred in the cemetery of Hamilton College, of which Kirkland was a co-founder.

* Skenandoa is Oneida for "hemlock".

This song represents how I feel for a relationship. I think someone is beautiful, but looks aren't everything. I love someone for the strength of the relationship and their personality.


Don't look for appearance, we will age as we grow old (which is still beautiful, but some people might understand what I mean here).
Don't look for people with soft skin, they eventually turn wrinkly.
Don't look for wealthy people, as money goes down the drain quickly.


It doesn't mean you can't have a relationship with these people, just saying it isn't the end of the world if you fall in love with someone that doesn't look as you want them to.

It's crazy how a song can hit different at particular  moments of your life. One year ago, I met a guy,  and I strangely fell in love with him instantly. I used to listen to this song all the time by that time. We shared some really great memories together that I will never forget, but we never dared admit we loved each other. Then, school year ended so fast because of the pandemic, and we didn't get to say goodbye. A few days ago, he told me he will go in another high school next year, so we won't see each other again. So I'm here, listening to this song that used to make me feel so happy and more in love that I was, and now hurt me so bad. I know I will miss him, and that school will never be the same without him, and our loud laughs, cause he knew so well how to make me laugh, and God knows it's a hard task. Maybe someday I will get over it, but at the moment it's really complicated. Our songs will always be OUR songs, I promise you, I will not forget you. You're a way too unforgettable for this Honey ;)

First off, I'm not what you'd call an Avril Lavigne fan; most of the music I listen to is tons of alternative rock and pop from from 80s and early 90s. HOWEVER, the other day while driving my wife was listening to her late 90s/early 2000s pop mix on Spotify and this song came up. It instantly transported me back to my life during the early 2000s which by no means was a fairy tale, but it might as well be given the hell hole our society has become over the last several years. Those were much brighter, optimistic, and fun times without question. Hearing this song made me miss people, places, and things I haven't seen in nearly 20 years. I only cared for my daughter being happy, not so much about the music itself, - except this very song, that I fell in love with right away. Never got tired of listening to it. Years of innocence and of lost paradise. Thanks Britney for the joy you brought in our family.

The Punk Show by Avril Lavigne official: No matter what anyone thinks of Avril for me, as a guitar teacher, Avril was great in the 2000's. So many young students came to me wanting to learn her tunes. For a lot of my students Avril was the first music they ever played on guitar. To see a young kid walking out of the studio I teach out of feeling empowered because they can play the music they love, well... Nothing will ever beat that feeling, so it doesn't matter what I or anyone else thinks of her music. She inspired an entire generation. That's important, and I got to watch that happen in real time.

I stagehanded a small festival that Avril headlined in the early aughts. There were rumblings all day that she was super sick and going to cancel. When it was time for her set to start, she had to be carried to the side of the stage, puked in the trash can next to the stairs. Then she hauled herself up onto the stage and performed her guts out for an hour before saying goodnight, walking off stage, and basically collapsing. None of the middle schoolers that looked up to her and came out to see her would have had any idea.
Her music's still not my thing, but that's seriously bad ass and I've had total respect for her since then.

I was 19 when Avril Lavigne broke big and was knee deep in hardcore (especially ebullition, level-plane, robotic empire, gravity, gold standard labs, etc underground "screamo" type stuff). Being that into DIY hardcore, I wasn't watching MTV and hardly ever listened to the radio. I think I heard the first three Avril Lavigne singles (how could you avoid them?) and couldn't have given a damn about the punk influence. I knew it wasn't "real" punk, whatever that is, but was past the point in my life where I was insecure enough to care. I feel like every fan of a genre which is very tribal/"underground"/community based eventually reached a turning point they realize that "fake" versions of what they are into, or younger people who are "posers" are some of the least important things in the entire world.

All these years later, my daughter is hooked on her back catalogue as if it came out yesterday. She was 9 when she discovered her, changed her look overnight and now, at 12, still sings her songs with a belting passion and is introducing me to cool new music that would have completely passed me by. That is legacy.

Always liked Avril. Even during my elitist days I've always thought that her first two albums were great. 

But it's clear that her popularity was primarily based around her image rather than her music. Cause her music early on draws very little from pop-punk. Save for a couple of songs. (And I don't think that's enough to classify her as such)

Just going based solely off of the music she creates. She can basically be summed up as the post-grunge version of Alanis Morrissette. I hear way more Alanis, Shania, and Staind in her than I do Green Day or Good Charlotte. 

Also don't understand why people label her as manufactured either. To me that label gets thrown around too often and is more so used to try and delegitimize the success of an artist for no valid reason. If we want to be technical here... Most bands and artists that get on Top 40 stations have to get there with SOME level of help. It's not always JUST about the music, And those artists don't always get a choice. 

Nickelback for example wrote songs for the purpose of getting them played on radio stations, And Linkin Park had to simplify their lyricism on their debut album since the labels wouldn't accept them otherwise. If we want to talk manufactured... Puddle Of Mudd technically falls under that category since every member of that band besides Wes Scantlin was hand selected by Fred Durst, And they got airplay based primarily on his influence. But nobody ever thinks of them as such.

Point is, Most big name artists are manufactured to a point. I wouldn't call Avril anymore manufactured than most 2000's artists/bands. And to act like some label just magically put together her image as a pop-punk/post-grunge icon is just ridiculous. Her songs made it big with outside help yes, But her image itself was big because it was genuine. She was a young girl that made the kind of music she wanted to make, The label couldn't produce that themselves.
